title-group.article-title: Identification and characterization of (+)-α-bisabolol and 7-epi-silphiperfol- 5-ene synthases from Artemisia abrotanum

sec.title: N/A
sec.p:
Identification and characterization of (+)-α- bisabolol and 7- epi -silphiperfol-5-ene synthases from
Artemisia abrotanum
Paskorn Muangphrom a , Momoka Misaki a , Munenori Suzuki a,b,c , Masaya Shimomura c ,

Hideyuki Suzuki d , Hikaru Seki
a,c,
∗ , Toshiya Muranaka a,c

a
Department of Biotechnology, Graduate School of Engineering, Osaka University 2-1 Yamadaoka, Suita, Osaka , 565-0871, Japan

b
KNC Laboratories Co., Ltd., 3-2-34 Takatsukadai , Nishi-ku , Kobe , Hyogo , 651-2271, Japan

c
Kihara Institute for Biological Research , Yokohama City University 641-12 Maioka-cho , Totsuka-ku , Yokohama , Kanagawa , 244-0813, Japan
d Department of Applied Genomics , Kazusa DNA Research Institute , 2-6-7 Kazusa-kamatari , Kisarazu , Chiba , 292-0818, Japan
A R T I C L E I N F O

sec.title: Keywords:
sec.p:
Artemisia abrotanum
L . Asteraceae
Sesquiterpenoid profiling Sesquiterpene synthase Triquinane-type sesquiterpenoid (+)-α- Bisabolol synthase 7- Epi -Silphiperfol-5-ene synthase AabrBOS
AabrSPS
A B S T R A C T

Triquinane is a type of sesquiterpenoid with a unique structure that contains a fused tricyclopentane ring and exhibits a wide range of bioactivities. Like other sesquiterpenoids, the first committed step in triquinane-type sesquiterpenoid biosynthesis is the cyclization of farnesyl pyrophosphate (FPP), a common precursor of all sesquiterpenoids, catalyzed by sesquiterpene synthase.
Artemisia abrotanum
L . ( Asteraceae ), a common plant used in the culinary and cosmetics industries, has been reported to accumulate high levels of triquinane silphiperfol-5-en-3-one A . This compound is potentially biosynthesized from the cyclization of FPP into 7- epi - silphiperfol-5-ene followed by a multi-step oxidation to silphiperfol-5-en-3-one A . In this study, we aimed to identify the sesquiterpene synthase responsible for the synthesis of 7- epi -silphiperfol-5-ene. We performed RNA sequencing of
A . abrotanum
leaves and gene candidates were mined by homology searches using the triquinane α- isocomene synthase of chamomile (MrTPS2) as query. After gene cloning, we obtained five variants of putative sesquiterpene synthase showing greater than 85% amino acid identity to MrTPS2 and greater than 95% amino acid identity to each other. Heterologous expression of these variants in a FPP-high-producing yeast strain revealed the first four variants to be (+)-α- bisabolol synthases (AabrBOS1–4). However, the fifth candidate cyclized FPP into 7- epi -silphiperfol-5-ene and can therefore be defined as a 7- epi -silphiperfol-5-ene synthase (AabrSPS). These findings revealed the first committed enzyme involved in silphiperfol-5-en-3-one A and (+)-αbisabolol biosyntheses in
A . abrotanum
. Furthermore, the results of this study will be useful for enhancing the production of these compounds for further applications.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: https://doi.org/ 10.1016/j.phytochem.2019.05.010

Our research group has been interested in the chemical diversity of sesquiterpenoids and their biosynthesis in
Artemisia spp.
( Asteraceae ), and previously published our studies on the discovery of three sesquiterpene synthases: koidzumiol synthase from
A . absinthium
L . (AabKOS), (+)-α- bisabolol synthases from
A . kurramensis Qazilb.
and
A . maritima
L . (AkBOS and AmBOS), and 4-amorphen-11-ol synthase from
A . maritima (AmAOS)
(
,
). Among the compounds that have been isolated from more than 400
Artemisia spp.
(
), the antimalarial artemisinin, from
Artemisia annua
L ., is the most renowned bioactive sesquiterpene, while other
Artemisia species
also accumulate a wide variety of sesquiterpenoids with interesting pharmaceutical and biomedical properties. In particular,
A . abrotanum
L . ( Asteraceae ), a common plant used in the culinary and cosmetic industries and for the treatment of various disorders and diseases of the upper respiratory tract (
;
), accumulates high levels of silphiperfol-5-en-3- one A , a triquinane-type sesquiterpenoid (
; Radulovi ć et al., 2009;
). Silphiperfol-5-en-3-one A and its derivatives are known for their odoriferous properties which can be developed and used as insect repellents, preservatives, and perfumes (
). Silphiperfol-5-en-3-one A can be synthesized from the cyclization of FPP into 7- epi -silphiperfol-5-ene followed by a multi-step oxidation, as shown in Fig. 1 . However, little is known about its biosynthesis, including the enzymes involved in the pathway. We therefore started to investigate possible enzymes responsible for the biosynthesis of silphiperfol-5-en-3-one A in
A . abrotanum
. In this study, we performed transcriptome sequencing of
A . abrotanum
leaves and mined a candidate gene potentially encoding 7- epi -silphiperfol-5-ene synthase based on amino acid sequence similarity to MrTPS2. After gene cloning and in vivo enzymatic functional analysis, we discovered a sesquiterpene synthase synthesizing 7- epi -silphiperfol-5-ene. Thus, we named this enzyme 7- epi -silphiperfol-5-ene synthase (AabrSPS). In addition, we also discovered four variants of (+)-α- bisabolol synthase (AabrBOS1–4) from
A . abrotanum
.

mixed-citation.named-content: Identification and characterization of (+)-α-bisabolol and 7-epi-silphiperfol- 5-ene synthases from Artemisia abrotanum

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Sesquiterpenoid profiles of two different strains of
A . abrotanum
were analyzed. GC-MS analyses of n- hexane extracts of the aerial parts of
A . abrotanum
revealed 15 sesquiterpenoids, tentatively identified based on comparisons of retention indices and mass spectra with those of authentic compounds and reference data (
and Table 1 ; Adams, 2007 ). β- Caryophyllene, germacrene D, bicyclogermacrene, and silphiperfolane-type sesquiterpenoids have been previously identified in
A . abrotanum
( Obistioiu et al., 2014 ; Radulovi ć et al., 2009; Wang et al., 2018 ), whereas detection of β- and δ- elemenes, α- and βcopaenes, and α- humulene in this study is the first report of these compounds in
A . abrotanum
. Among all detected compounds, tricyclic silphiperfol-5-en-3-one A occupied 60% of the total sesquiterpenoid content of the extract. This finding strongly supported that the as yet unidentified gene encoding silphiperfolene synthase is highly expressed in the
A . abrotanum
used in this study.

sec.title: 2.2. Cloning of putative sesquiterpene synthases
Orphanage

sec.p:
b RI on HP-5MS column which were reported in
.

c
A. abrotanum
strain 1 which was purchased from a local herb store in Japan.

A. abrotanum
strain 2 which was provided by Ocean Exposition Commemorative Park Management Foundation.

sec.title: 2.3. In vivo enzymatic assay of putative sesquiterpene synthases
sec.p:
For functional identification, AabrBOS1–4 and AabrSPS were individually expressed in the FPP-high-producing
Saccharomyces cerevisiae
strain EPY300 (
,
). After culturing, in vivo metabolites were extracted and analyzed by GC-MS. As shown in Fig. 4A and B , AabrBOS1–4 each yielded the same reaction product, compound 1 [retention time (RT) = 12.13 min] as a major product, while AabrSPS produced compound 2 (RT = 8.04 min) as a major product. Note that compound 2 differed from compound
1 in
both RT and mass fragmentation pattern. Neither compound was detected from the yeast strain that had been transformed with the empty control vector. The estimated yield of each product, relative to the concentration of the internal standard n- tetradecane, with AabrBOS1–4 and AabrSPS was 355, 318, 507, 326, and 68 mg /l, respectively. Tyrosol, 2,4-di- tert -butyl phenol, nerolidol, and farnesol are endogenously produced in
S . cerevisiae
(
;
). The mass spectra of these endogenous compounds are shown in Fig. S3.

sec.title: 2.4. AabrBOS1–4 are (+)- α -bisabolol synthases
sec.p:
Four variants of (+)-α- bisabolol synthase were identified in
A . abrotanum
. However, (+)-α- bisabolol and its related compounds were not detected in the crude n- hexane extracts of this plant ( Fig. S1 and Table 1 ). Although this result is consistent with those of
, Radulovi ć et al. (2009) detected certain (+)-α- bisabolol derivatives; i.e ., α- bisabolol oxide A and its acetate form, in this plant. This difference suggests that most of the (+)-α- bisabolol produced by
A . abrotanum
may be converted to its derivatives ( Fig. 1 ) and the remaining quantity of (+)-α- bisabolol was too low to be detected in the current study. Also note that the sesquiterpenoid profile of the same plant species can vary depending on the plant cultivar and the environmental conditions during growth.
(caption on next page)

sec.title: 2.5. AabrSPS is 7-epi-silphiperfol-5-ene synthase
3. Conclusions
sec.p:
Silphiperfol-5-en-3-one A is a major triquinane sesquiterpenoid found in
A . abrotanum
. In an attempt to identify the sesquiterpene synthase responsible for the biosynthesis of silphiperfol-5-en-3-one A , we performed transcriptome sequencing of
A . abrotanum
leaves and mined the candidates using the previously identified triquinane sesquiterpene synthase MrTPS2 as query. After gene cloning, we obtained five variants of putative sesquiterpene synthase. An in vivo enzymatic assay against FPP in yeast revealed four of the variants, namely AabrBOS1–4, to be specific (+)-α- bisabolol synthases. This is the first report of this enzyme in
A . abrotanum
. The last variant, namely AabrSPS, was identified as a 7- epi -silphiperfol-5-ene synthase synthesizing 7- epi -silphiperfol-5-ene, the biosynthetic precursor of silphiperfol-5-en-3-one A . This enzyme is the first known committed enzyme in silphiperfol-5-en-3-one A biosynthesis in
A . abrotanum
. Its discovery and characterization will significantly simplify the production of triquinane-type sesquiterpenoids for further studies.

sec.title: 4.1. Plant materials, yeast strain and chemicals
sec.p:
Two different strains of
Artemisia abrotanum
L . ( Asteraceae ) were obtained. Strain 1 was purchased from a local herb store, Maypop ( Fukuoka , Japan ). Strain 2 was kindly provided by the Ocean Exposition Commemorative Park Management Foundation ( Okinawa , Japan ). The plants were cultivated in Jiffymix (Sakata Seed Corporation, Yokohama, Japan ) and Sanyaso-no-tsuchi (Ohmiya Green Service, Saitama , Japan ) under natural light and environmental conditions at the Kihara Institute for Biological Research (35̊24′ N, 139̊33 E), located in Yokohama, Japan , and harvested in May 2008 with an average monthly temperature of 18.0 ̊ C and relative humidity of 70%. The collected young leaves of
A . abrotanum
strain 1 were frozen in liquid nitrogen and stored at −80 ̊ C until used for total RNA extraction.

The yeast
Saccharomyces cerevisiae EPY
300 strain of genotype
MAT αα his3
Δ 1 leu2 Δ 0 lys2 Δ 0 ura3 Δ 0 P GAL1-tHMGR P GAL1-upc2-1 erg9 : PMET3-ERG9 P GAL1-tHMGR P GAL1-ERG20 was previously developed to increase FPP production (
,
).

n -Tetradecane and (-)-α- bisabolol were purchased from SigmaAldrich (St. Louis, MO, USA ). Silica gel 100N (spherical, neutral, particle size 100–230 μm) was purchased from Kanto Chemical Industry ( Tokyo , Japan ). The 10% AgNO 3 impregnated silica gel was purchased from Wako Pure Chemical Industries ( Osaka , Japan ). Alkane standard mixture ( C 10– C 20) was purchased from GL-Sciences ( Tokyo , Japan ). Other chemicals and solvents were purchased from Kishida Chemical Co., Ltd. ( Osaka , Japan ).
4.2. Sesquiterpenoid profiling of A. abrotanum L

The aerial parts of
A . abrotanum
L. ( 320 mg ) were extracted three times with n -hexane. After drying over anhydrous Na 2 SO 4 , the extracts were concentrated under reduced pressure and a flow of nitrogen gas before being re-dissolved in 1 ml n- hexane for GC-MS analysis as described in 4.7. Sesquiterpenoids were identified from comparisons of GC retention indices and mass spectra with those of authentic compounds and reference data (
). n -Tetradecane was used for the quantification of each detected sesquiterpenoid and alkane standard mixture (C10–C20) was used to determine retention indices.

sec.title: 4.3. RNA extraction and library construction
sec.p: Total RNA was extracted from frozen leaves using PureLink Plant RNA Reagent (ThermoFisher Scientific, Waltham, MA, USA ), treated with recombinant DNaseI (RNase-free) (Takara Bio, Shiga , Japan ), and purified using the RNeasy Plant Mini Kit (Qiagen, Hilden, Germany ) following the RNA clean-up protocol.

sec.title: 4.4. Cloning of AabrBOS1–4 and AabrSPS
sec.p:
First-strand cDNA was synthesized from 1 μg total RNA prepared from
A . abrotanum
leaves using the SMARTer RACE cDNA Amplification Kit (Clontech/TaKaRa Bio) according to the manufacturer's instructions. To obtain the missing 5′ and 3′ end sequences of a contig (1,303 bp) containing the partial ORF of a putative tricyclic sesquiterpene synthase, 5′-RACE PCR using primers 1 (first) and 2 (nested), and 3′-RACE PCR using primers 3 (first) and 4 (nested) were performed. Using sequence information obtained by RACE-PCR, primers 5 and 6 were designed to amplify a complete ORF. The complete ORFs of AabrBOS s and AabrSPS were amplified using PrimeSTAR Max DNA Polymerase (Takara Bio) and the amplified product was cloned into a pENTR/D-TOPO (ThermoFisher Scientific) and sequenced. The sequences of all primers used in this study are listed in Supplementary Table S5. The nucleotide sequences isolated in this study have been submitted to DDBJ under the accession numbers LC469617 (AabrBOS1), LC469618 (AabrBOS2), LC469619 (AabrBOS3), LC469620 (AabrBOS4), and LC469621 (AabrSPS), respectively.

sec.title: 4.5. Phylogenetic analysis
4.6. In vivo enzymatic assay and product isolation
sec.p:
The complete ORF of AabrBOS s and AabrSPS was transferred via pENTR/D-TOPO into a pYES-DEST52 (ThermoFisher Scientific) vector using Gateway LR Clonase II Enzyme Mix (ThermoFisher Scientific) to construct expression clones. Expression clones were introduced into
S . cerevisiae
strain EPY300. Yeast cells harboring the pYES2/CT empty vector (ThermoFisher Scientific) were used as a negative control. Transgenic yeast cells were cultured as described previously (
). Cells of the resulting cultures were then disrupted by sonication at room temperature for 30 min and extracted three times with EtOAc (for yeast expressing AabrBOS ) or EtOEt (for yeast expressing AabrSPS ). After drying the combined organic layer over anhydrous Na 2 SO 4 , the samples were concentrated under reduced pressure with a flow of nitrogen gas. Crude extracts were further purified by silica gel column chromatography and analyzed by GC-MS as described in 4.7 . The chemical structures of the purified compounds were analyzed with a Bruker AVANCE III HD 600 MHz NMR spectrometer (Bruker, Osaka , Japan ) using CDCl 3 as a solvent. Chemical shifts are reported as δ (ppm) relative to those of the internal standard tetramethylsilane ( δH = 0 ppm) or CDCl 3 ( δH = 7.24 ppm, δC = 77.0 ppm). The absolute configuration of the α- bisabolol product of AabrBOS1 was identified from its optical rotation using a JASCO P-1020 polarimeter (JASCO, Tokyo , Japan ) with a 50-mm microcell (1 mL) as compared with that of standard (-)-α- bisabolol. Endogenous compounds produced in yeast, tyrosol, di- tert -butyl phenol, nerolidol, and farnesol, were identified by comparison of their mass spectra with those available in the NIST mass spectral library (The NIST Mass Spectral Search Program for the NIST/EPA/NIH Mass Spectral Library version 2.2, 2014).

sec.title: 4.7. GC-MS analysis
sec.p:
For sesquiterpenoid profiling of
A . abrotanum , GC-MS
analysis was performed using a 6890 A gas chromatograph (Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, CA, USA ) connected to a JMS-AM SUN200 mass spectrometer (JEOL, Tokyo , Japan ) and HP-5MS capillary column ( 30 m × 0.25 mm i.d., film thickness 0.25 μm; J&W Scientific, Santa Clara, CA, USA ) with a fused silica capillary tube ( 1 m × 0.25 mm i.d., GL-Sciences). The temperature program began at 60 ̊ C and increased at a rate of 3 ̊ C /min to 280 ̊ C where it was held for 6 min and 40 s.

For the in vivo enzymatic assay, GC-MS analysis was performed using a 7890B gas chromatograph (Agilent Technologies) connected to a 5977 A MSD mass spectrometer (Agilent Technologies) and HP-5MS capillary column with a fused silica capillary tube of the same length and internal diameter as those described above. The temperature program was held at 100 ̊ C for 2 min and increased at a rate of 10 ̊ C /min to 280 ̊ C where it was held for 5 min.

In all analyses, the injection port temperature was set at 250 ̊ C . The carrier gas was He, and the flow rate was set to 0.7 ml/min. Split injection (1 μL) was conducted at a ratio of 1:10. The scanning speed of the mass spectrometer was two scans/s from m/z 40–350 at an electron voltage of 70 eV.
Conflicts of interest
None.

sec.title: Acknowledgements
sec.p:
We are grateful to the Ocean Exposition Commemorative Park Management Foundation ( Okinawa , Japan ) for providing
A. abrotanum
plants. We thank Dr. Kyoko Inoue ( Osaka University) for technical support with NMR analysis, Mr. Tsutomu Hosouchi and Ms. Sayaka Shinpo (Kazusa DNA Research Institute) for technical support with the Illumina sequencing. This work was supported by Grant-in-Aid for Scientific Research on Innovative Areas, Nos. JP17H05442 and JP19H04657 to H.Seki.

sec.title: Appendix A . Supplementary data
sec.p: Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https:// doi.org/10.1016/j.phytochem.2019.05.010.
